Hi Gordon,
Ah, sorry for jumping in being ignorant of past conversation!

But let me say, using low-default open-files limit is not the point of 
my post. Our crawlers have been doing just fine with that low-limit with 
200-300 threads, running for 20+ days, until we encounter too many open 
files error last week. We were not sure if it actually hit the limit for 
good reason, or some other factors were at play. Before raising the 
limit, I wanted to know what's really happening inside. What I found was 
surge in number of DNS UDP sockets, and ~400 files which I don't know if 
I have control on. I'm sorry if such information is not useful.

While it is easy to raise limit to big number, also it is good to know 
things are in control. For us, slowing down crawl a bit is much better 
than getting BDB destroyed!

Thanks,
Kenji

(12/22/10 9:58 PM), Gordon Mohr wrote:
> Based on prior exchanges with Adam, I think his problem is other than
> hitting the low-default 1024 open-files limit, which I believe he's
> already raised. (Notably, my understanding is that his crawl ran for
> weeks with 300 threads before encountering problems -- though perhaps,
> something has reverted the limit.) I've asked him separately for more
> information that might narrow down the cause.
>
> Anyone doing non-trivial crawling should increase their open-files limit
> before launching Heritrix, as noted in the older H1-based FAQ...
>
> http://crawler.archive.org/faq.html#toomanyopenfiles
>
> You'll find similar advice for many other IO-intensive packages -- for
> example the Lucene, HBase, Hypertable, and other FAQs have similar entries.
>
> We should probably add a more prominent warning in the various H1/H3
> getting started docs, and (if practical) even do a sanity-check on
> launch that warns people who haven't already raised this limit.
>
> Historically, most crawling machines at IA have had this limit raised to
> 32768, though it can harmlessly be much larger as well. Kenji, I'm not
> sure why your machines would have still had the impractically-small
> default limit.
>
> - Gordon @ IA
>
> On 12/22/10 3:19 PM, Kenji Nagahashi wrote:
>> Hi Adam,
>>
>> Coincidentally, I've been investigating the same "too many open files"
>> error in our crawl projects. Based on what I've found so far, it appears
>> Heritrix hit per-process maximum of open file descriptors (1024 in our
>> case). Following is what I learned from monitoring 5 hour test crawl
>> (Heritrix 3) - probably the something similar must be happening in your
>> crawl project, too.
>>
>> Heritrix 3 has ~80 always-open file descriptors for JARs, log files,
>> ARC/WARCs, BDB and listening sockets.
>>
>> Each active crawling thread can open up to 3 file descriptors at one
>> time for fetching and recording HTTP request/response. Our crawler is
>> configured with max 200 threads, so there can be up to 600 open file
>> descriptors at one time, but usually much less than that (max 318 in our
>> case).
>>
>> In addition to total 400 open fds above, there are other 4 kinds of file
>> descriptors, which reached 400 in total during the test. Now it is
>> pretty close to per-process limit of 1024.
>>
>> One of "additional" open descriptors is UDP socket for DNS query. I saw
>> max 75 sockets open at one time. If DNS server gets overloaded and slows
>> down, there could be more.
>>
>> Also as crawl job proceed, BDB gets bigger and BDB seems to keep more
>> database files open.
>>
>> Summing up, with following factors combined, Heritrix could run out of
>> file descriptors and start failing severely:
>>
>> - many threads
>> - shallow crawl on many web sites (such crawl can go very fast, too)
>> - long-running crawl
>> - slow DNS queries
>>
>> Probably crawling with less threads is the easiest (but not so reliable)
>> way to prevent this problem, but Heritrix could do a kind of throttling
>> by limiting the number of concurrent DNS queries.
>>
>> Kenji @ Internet Archive
>>
